CERTIFICATE AS TO PARTIES, RULINGS,  
AND RELATED CASES 
A.  Parties and Amici 
Plaintiff is Lisa D. Cook, in her official capacity as a member of the 
Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and her personal 
capacity. Defendants are Donald J. Trump, in his official capacity as 
President of the United States of America; the Board of Governors of the 
Federal Reserve System both collectively and in their individual official 
capacities; and Jerome H. Powell, in his official capacity as Chair of the 
Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.  
Azoria Capital, Inc. and James T. Fishback appeared as amici curiae 
in the district court. K.L. Smith, Jason Goodman, Martin Akerman, and 
William Michael Cunningham filed pro se motions to appear as amici 
curiae. There have been no intervenors. 
The Separation of Powers Clinic has moved to file an amicus brief in 
support of defendants in this Court.  
B.   Ruling Under Review 
The ruling under review is an order granting a preliminary injunction 
(Dkt. 28) and opinion (Dkt. 27) that the district court (Judge Jia M. Cobb) 
issued on September 9, 2025. The opinion and order are attached to this 
motion.  
 
 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 3 of 18
 
C.   Related Cases 
This case has not previously been before this Court. 
Wilcox v. Trump, No. 25-5057 (D.C. Cir.); Harris v. Bessent, No. 25-
5055 (D.C. Cir.); Grundmann v. Trump, No. 25-5165 (D.C. Cir.); Slaughter 
v. Trump, No. 25-5261 (D.C. Cir.), and Boyle v. Trump, No. 25-1687 (4th 
Cir.), involve challenges to the Presidentโs removal of principal officers 
from multimember agencies with statutory removal restrictions. 
/s/ Laura E. Myron 
Laura E. Myron 
Attorney, Appellate Staff 
Civil Division 
U.S. Department of Justice 
950 Pennsylvania Avenue NW 
Washington, DC 20530 
(202) 305-1754 
 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 4 of 18
TABLE OF CONTENTS 
Page 
INTRODUCTION ............................................................................................ 1 
ARGUMENT ................................................................................................... 2 
I.  The Presidentโs โCauseโ Determination Is Not Subject To 
Judicial Second Guessing ..................................................................... 3 
II.  The District Court Misconstrued โFor Causeโ ...................................... 5 
III.  Cookโs Due-Process Claim Fails ........................................................... 8 
IV.  The Remaining Factors Support A Stay .............................................. 11 
CONCLUSION ............................................................................................... 13 
CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE 
 
 
 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 5 of 18
INTRODUCTION  
Removal โfor causeโ is a capacious standard that Congress has vested 
in the Presidentโs discretion. Even if the Presidentโs determination were 
reviewableโand over a century of caselaw suggests it is notโreview would 
be limited to the rigorous standard for ultra vires claims. Cook does not 
argue that she meets that standard, nor could she. The district courtโs 
conclusion that โcauseโ excludes pre-confirmation conduct finds no 
support in text or precedent, and even Cookโs counsel did not advocate for 
that standard below.  
Cookโs due-process claim is equally meritless. We are aware of no 
case extending due-process protections for employees to principal officers 
of the United States, and nothing in the text of 12 U.S.C. ยง 242 purports to 
do so. That makes good senseโunlike โcivil servantsโ who generally do not 
wield โsignificant authority,โ Free Enterprise Fund v. PCAOB, 561 U.S. 477, 
506 (2010), principal officers help the President discharge constitutional 
duties and wield significant executive power, Seila Law LLC v. CFPB, 591 
U.S. 197, 203-04 (2020). Requiring the President to afford them a โformal 
evidentiary hearingโ (Op. 38) before removal is untenable. And even if 
Cook had a property interest in her office, she still has provided no basis to 
believe that a hearing would have made a difference. 
 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 6 of 18
 
ARGUMENT 
I.   The Presidentโs โCauseโ Determination Is Not Subject 
to Judicial Second-Guessing 
A. When a statute gives a power of removal โfor cause,โ without any 
specification of the causes, the removal decision โis a matter of discretion 
and not reviewable.โ Reagan v. United States, 182 U.S. 419, 425 (1901); see 
Mot. 8-9. Cook asserts (Opp. 6) that Reaganโs non-reviewability holding 
applies only to offices without fixed terms. But the sentence above did not 
rely on the petitionerโs lack of a fixed term. And there is no reason to think 
the Presidentโs discretionary determination of what constitutes cause is any 
more amenable to judicial review simply because it concerns an officer with 
a fixed term. This Court has confirmed as much by holding that a fixed term 
of office โis a ceiling, not a floor, on the length of service,โ Severino v. 
Biden, 71 F.4th 1038, 1045 (D.C. Cir. 2023)โso a fixed term alone confers 
no removal protection at all. Accord Parsons v. United States, 167 U.S. 324, 
335, 343 (1897) (similar). 
Even if Reagan were factually distinguishable, Cook does not refute 
the contemporaneous treatise announcing the same rule or the series of 
state-court decisions demonstrating that courts broadly understood the 
2 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 7 of 18
 
power to remove for โcauseโ was discretionary and unreviewable.1  
B. At minimum, Cook would have to show that the President acted 
ultra vires. Accord Compl. ยถ 66 (alleging that removal was โultra vires and 
a clear violation of lawโ). Cook has identified no statutory cause of action, 
and her objection is that the President exceeded his statutory authority. The 
only available form of judicial review is therefore an ultra vires claim. See 
Federal Express Corp. v. U.S. Depโt of Commerce, 39 F.4th 756, 763 (D.C. 
Cir. 2022).  
Cook argues that Wiener v. United States, 357 U.S. 349 (1958), 
means review is not limited to ultra vires review. But Wiener was a suit for 
backpay; that is wholly different from a โnonstatutory reviewโ suit โseeking 
injunctive reliefโโin other words, what is โcommonly known as an ultra 
vires claim.โ Federal Express, 39 F.4th at 763.  
This Court has made clear that ultra vires claims are reserved for 
instances of โextremeโ error; action that is โโpatently a misconstruction of 
the Act, that disregards a specific and unambiguous statutory directive, or 
that violates some specific command of a statute.โ Changji Esquel Textile 
 
1 Montgomery H. Throop, A Treatise on the Law Relating to Public Officers 
ยง 396, at 387 (1892); see also, e.g., United States ex rel. Garland v. Oliver, 6 
Mackey 47, 53, 56 (D.C. 1887); Trimble v. People, 34 P. 981, 985 (Colo. 1893); 
City of Hoboken v. Gear, 3 Dutch. 265, 288 (N.J. 1859); People v. Stout, 19 
How. Pr. 171 (N.Y. Sup. Ct. Gen. Term 1860) (opinion of Sutherland, J.). 
3 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 8 of 18
 
Co. v. Raimondo, 40 F.4th 716, 722 (D.C. Cir. 2022).2 Cook must show that 
the President โhas plainly and openly crossed a congressionally drawn line 
in the sand.โ Federal Express, 39 F.4th at 765; see also Nuclear Regulatory 
Commโn v. Texas, 605 U.S. 665, 681 (2025).  
While Federal Express and Changji Esquel considered challenges to 
agency, not residential, action, that difference if anything makes Cookโs 
burden even higher. Even assuming presidential action is subject to an 
ultra vires claim, โreview must be exceedingly deferentialโ given the 
โPresidentโs discretion in exercising core Article II responsibilities.โ 
American Foreign Service Association v. Trump, 2025 WL 1742853, at *2 
(D.C. Cir. June 20, 2025) (granting stay pending appeal). 
The governmentโs reading is far from โutterly unreasonable,โ Federal 
Express, 39 F.4th at 766, it is correct. And the Presidentโs determination 
that Cookโs financial misrepresentation constituted sufficient cause for 
removal is both an unreviewable exercise of the discretion Congress vested 
in him, see Dalton v. Specter, 511 U.S. 462, 477 (1994), and eminently 
 
2 Cook suggests that the government waived reliance on the ultra 
vires standard by raising it for the first time on appeal. But Cook pled 
Count I of her complaint as an ultra vires claim and the government 
responded that there was no โclear-cut abuse of discretion warranting 
judicial intervention.โ Dkt. 23 at 5. In all events, ultra vires is the only 
possible cause of action given the lack of a statutory review provision.  
4 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 9 of 18
 
reasonable, as it concerns whether Cook can be trusted to act with 
forthrightness, care, and disinterest in managing the U.S. money supply. 
II.   The District Court Misconstrued โFor Causeโ 
Under any standard, an apparent misrepresentation in loan 
documents that garners a financial benefit to the applicant is enough to 
justify removing someone from a senior financial regulatory role. โ[F]or 
causeโ in its ordinary usage clearly encompasses such a determination, and 
nothing in the statute forbids consideration of misconduct that concerns a 
personal matter, that occurs at a certain time, or that may not result in a 
criminal conviction. 
The district court erred when it imposed additional restrictions on the 
Presidentโs removal power that do not appear in the statutory text. Neither 
the statute nor the contemporaneous 1933 Blackโs Law Dictionary 
definition of the term โfor causeโ contains an โin officeโ limitation. See 12 
U.S.C. ยง 242; Blackโs Law Dictionary 796 (3d ed. 1933) (defining โfor 
causeโ); but see Op. 13-19. โIt is a fundamental principle of statutory 
interpretation that โabsent provision[s] cannot be supplied by the courts.โโ 
Little Sisters of the Poor Saints Peter & Paul Home v. Pennsylvania, 591 
U.S. 657, 677 (2020) (quoting Rotkiske v. Klemm, 589 U.S. 8, 14 (2019)). 
That โprinciple applies not only to adding terms not found in the statute, 
5 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 10 of 18
 
but also to imposing limits on an agencyโs discretion that are not supported 
by the text.โ Id. In construing โfor causeโ to be limited to only conduct 
occurring โin office,โ the court โalter[ed], rather than [] interpret[ed]โ the 
statute. Id.  
In defending the district courtโs narrow interpretation, Cook misses 
three dispositive points. First, โ[a]textual judicial supplementation is 
particularly inappropriate when, as here, Congress has shown that it knows 
how to adopt the omitted language or provision.โ Rotkiske, 589 U.S. at 14. 
Congress, in both contemporaneous statutes and those enacted since, 
expressly included an โin officeโ limitation, see e.g., 15 U.S.C. ยง 41 
(โmalfeasance in officeโ); 29 U.S.C. ยง 153 (same).3 Yet Congress instead 
chose โfor causeโ for the Federal Reserve Act. โFor causeโ contemplates a 
broader range of considerations because it is not limited to โin-officeโ 
grounds. The inference the district court drew from its survey of the U.S. 
Code was backwards, reading in limitations that Congress knew how to 
impose but did not.  
Second, Cookโs insistence that โfor causeโ is synonymous with 
 
3 See, e.g., 5 U.S.C. ยงยง 1202(d), 1211(b), 7104(b); 12 U.S.C. 
ยง 5491(c)(3); 26 U.S.C. ยง 7443(f); 29 U.S.C. ยง 661(b); 30 U.S.C. ยง 823(b)(1); 
38 U.S.C. ยง 7101(b)(2); 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 5841(e), 7171(b)(1), 7412(r)(6)(B); 45 
U.S.C. ยง 154; 46 U.S.C. ยง 46101(b)(5); 49 U.S.C. ยงยง 1111(c), 1301(b)(3). 
6 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 11 of 18
 
narrower formulations (Opp. 9-10) ignores that the Supreme Court has 
specifically contrasted these provisions, noting that โfor causeโ โappears to 
give the President more removal authority than other removal provisions.โ 
Collins v. Yellen, 594 U.S. 220, 255-56 (2021) (emphasis added). And 
precedent dating back centuries is in accord. Indeed, the district courtโs 
categorical exclusion of any pre-office misconduct from the domain of 
โcauseโ is refuted by the cases Cook cites (Opp. 10-11), which make clear 
that pre-confirmation misconduct can constitute โcauseโ for removal 
where, as here, it bears on the officerโs fitness to serve. 
Third, the district courtโs limiting construction of โcauseโ would 
prohibit the President from removing a principal officer when there is 
unrebutted evidence of serious misconduct bearing on her fitness for office. 
On the district courtโs theory, the President could not remove a Board 
Governor who was revealed to have committed massive financial fraudโ
provided it happened before confirmation. That cannot be right. And such a 
view would raise substantial questions under Article II.  
For all these reasons, Cookโs counsel was correct below to disclaim 
the categorical rule adopted by the district court. Hrโg Tr. at 17:10-25 (Aug. 
29, 2025). Cookโs position below was that pre-office misconduct could be 
grounds for removal, depending on careful balancing of factors, including 
7 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 12 of 18
 
severity, timing, and relevance to the office. See id. But the district court 
acknowledged that it would not second-guess the Presidentโs discretionary 
weighing of such factors, Op. 26 n.9, and instead adopted a bright-line rule 
urged by neither party. 
Finally, to the extent Cook suggests that the President removed her 
based on a policy disagreement relating to interest rates, that was not the 
basis of the district courtโs injunction and is incorrect. The Presidentโs letter 
made clear that he was acting based on her โdeceitful and potentially 
criminal conductโ in connection with the mortgage agreements. The Court 
should decline โto probe the sincerity of the [Presidentโs] stated 
justificationsโ for an action when the President has identified a facially 
permissible basis for it. Trump v. Hawaii, 585 U.S. 667, 702 (2018); see 
also American Foreign Serv. Assโn, 2025 WL 1742853, at *3 (explaining 
that Hawaii did not โinspectโ the Presidentโs โrationaleโ). 
III.   Cookโs Due-Process Claim Fails 
A โpublic office is not propertyโ and Cookโs role as a principal officer 
โto the public is inconsistent with either a property or a contract right.โ 
Taylor v. Beckham, 178 U.S. 548, 576-77 (1900). Cookโs reliance on 
Reagan and Shurtleff v. United States, 189 U.S. 311 (1903), is misplaced, as 
both cases concerned a statutory right to notice and a hearing, not the 
8 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 13 of 18
 
constitutional right on which the district court relied.4 And both cases 
upheld the removal of officers who did not receive a hearing. Nor does 
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. 137 (1803), help Cook, as it concerned 
Marburyโs โright to [a] commissionโ to demonstrate his appointment to an 
office, id. at 172-73, not whether he held a property interest in his office.  
Cookโs due-process argument fundamentally rests on her view that 
the property interest that tenured employees have in their jobs applies with 
full force to principal executive officers of the United States. Opp. 13. She 
cites no case that has so held. And her theory fundamentally 
misunderstands the purpose of removal restrictions. Congress has enacted 
statutory removal restrictions for various officers to ensure that they โact 
* * * independently of executive control,โ and โexercise [their] judgment 
without the leave or hindrance of any other official.โ Humphreyโs Executor 
v. United States, 295 U.S. 602, 629 (1935). Congress did not, in enacting 
restrictions for these purposes, confer on principal officers an individual 
proprietary interest in their office.  
 
4 Cook does renew her argument that the Federal Reserve Act entitled 
her to notice and a hearing before removal. But the district court did not 
adopt that argument. Op. 27-28. Nor should this Court. Congress knows 
how to confer these procedural protections and has done so elsewhere. See, 
e.g., 5 U.S.C. ยง 7104(b); 22 U.S.C. ยง 4135(d); 29 U.S.C. ยง 153(a); 38 U.S.C. 
ยง 7101(b)(2); 5 U.S.C. ยง 7521(a). It did not extend those protections to 
members of the Board of Governors. 
9 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 14 of 18
 
And there is no basis to extend cases considering property interests 
held by civil servants in their employment to the fundamentally different 
duties owed by constitutional officers to the citizenry. The Appointments 
Clause โcares not a whitโ about employees but controls the appointment of 
officers who wield โsignificant authority.โ Lucia v. SEC, 585 U.S. 237, 245 
(2018). โThe people do not vote for the โOfficers of the United States,โโ Free 
Enterprise, 561 U.S. at 497-98, who maintain their connection to the public 
through the Presidentโs oversight. A stake in the office for their own 
personal benefit is unsupported by precedent and incompatible with 
constitutional structure. 
In any event, Cook has not shown that a hearing would have made a 
difference. Even assuming she is right to insist that she was not required to 
bring any defense to the Presidentโs attention between August 20 (when the 
President put her on notice) and August 25 (when he effectuated the 
termination), she was requiredโas an, โessential elementโ of her due-
process claimโto identify what material facts were in dispute. Codd v. 
Velger, 429 U.S. 626, 627 (1977). Cook has failed to do so. She has no 
answer to Codd and has provided no explanation for the contradictory 
representations apparent on the face of her mortgage agreements, see Dkt. 
1-4 at 1, and that alone is grounds to stay the extraordinary equitable relief 
10 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 15 of 18
 
she secured below.  
IV.  The Remaining Factors Support A Stay 
Merits aside, the Supreme Court has made abundantly clear that โthe 
Government faces greater risk of harm from an order allowing a removed 
officer to continue exercising the executive powerโ than the removed officer 
faces from a stay. Trump v. Boyle, 145 S. Ct. 2653, 2654 (2025); accord 
Order, LeBlanc v. U.S. Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, No. 
25-5197 (D.C. Cir. July 1, 2025). Cook points out that the Court reserved 
whether the Federal Reserve removal restrictions might be constitutional 
even if other removal restrictions for executive officers are not. But that is a 
distinction going to the merits (and the constitutional issue has not even 
been presented here). On the equities, the Supreme Courtโs determinations 
in Wilcox and Boyle apply equally here. 
Cook asserts that the equities balance differently here because she 
supposedly โhas been continuously servingโ since the Presidentโs removal. 
Opp. 20. Assuming that were true, that only underscores the need for a 
stay, because, as the Supreme Court has emphasized, the โGovernment 
faces greater risk of harm from * * * allowing a removed officer to continue 
exercising the executive powerโ than the harm to the removed officer from 
a stay. Boyle, 145 S. Ct. at 2654. 
11 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 16 of 18
 
The rest of Cookโs arguments on the equitable factors rest on the 
notion that her removal reflects a โdesire to change policy at the Federal 
Reserve,โ thus implicating the value of Federal Reserve independence. Opp. 
19. The district court did not issue its injunction on that basis, however, Op. 
27 n. 10, and it provides no basis to deny a stay. The public and the 
Executive share an interest in ensuring the integrity of the Federal Reserve, 
and that requires respecting the Presidentโs statutory authority to remove 
Governors โfor causeโ when such cause arises. 
 
12 

USCA Case #25-5326      Document #2134769            Filed: 09/14/2025      Page 17 of 18
 
CONCLUSION 
The Court should stay the district courtโs injunction.  
Respectfully submitted,

i 
 

TABLE OF CONTENTS 
 
INTRODUCTION .....................................................................................................1   
STATEMENT OF THE CASE ..................................................................................3   
STANDARD OF REVIEW .......................................................................................5   
I.  The Presidentโs โCauseโ Determination is Subject to Judicial Review.
 ...............................................................................................................5   
II.  The is Government is Not Likely to Succeed on the Merits ................. 8 
A.  โFor Causeโ Does Not Mean โAt Will.โ .......................................... 8 
B.  The Presidentโs Attempt to Remove Governor Cook was Without 
โCauseโ .............................................................................................8   
1.  The District Court Correctly Concluded that Pre-Office 
Conduct Does Not Constitute Cause. ......................................... 8 
C.  Governor Cook Was Deprived of Her Statutory and Constitutional 
Rights to Notice and an Opportunity to Be Heard. ........................11 
III.  The Remaining Factors Favor Governor Cook. ..................................15 
CONCLUSION ........................................................................................................21 
 
 
   
ii 
 

INTRODUCTION 
For more than a century, Congress safeguarded the independence of the 
Federal  Reserve  through  statutory  protection  against  the  at-will  removal  of  its 
members.  A few months ago, the Supreme Court reaffirmed the importance of that 
statutory protection, emphasizing its long and distinct historical pedigree.  The Fed, 
the Court explained, is โa uniquely structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the 
distinct historical tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States.โ 
Trump v. Wilcox, 145 S. Ct. 1415 (2025).  President Trumpโs attempted removal of 
Governor Lisa Cook, if allowed, would mark an immediate end to that history.  And 
it would send a destabilizing signal to the financial markets that could not be easily 
undone.  
The  government  does  not  challenge  the  constitutionality  of  the  statutory 
removal protection guaranteeing the Boardโs independence. Yet it nevertheless asks 
this Court, on an emergency basis, to render that protection meaningless by reducing 
for-cause removal to a โmatter of discretionโ that is โnot reviewableโ by any court. 
Mot. at 1 (quoting Reagan v. United States, 182 U.S. 419, 425 (1901)).  And, worse 
still, the government asks the Court to abdicate its role in a case in which the 
attempted removal was announced without affording any notice or opportunity to be 
heardโcontrary to both the statute and constitutional due process.  That would 
transform the Federal Reserve from a historically independent institution into an at-
1 
 

will body, leaving the nationโs central bank (and its monetary policy) at the mercy 
of the White House and its political whims. 
That  is  the  opposite  of  what  Congress  intended.  And  it  is  therefore  the 
opposite of what the law requires. โFor cause,โ as a matter of black-letter law and 
common sense, โdoes not mean the same thing as โat will.โโ Collins v. Yellen, 594 
U.S. 220, 256 (2021) (alteration adopted).   
This Court can leave for another day any hard questions about the precise 
scope  of  a  Presidentโs  for-cause-removal  authority.    Under  any  plausible 
formulation, this removal is not for cause. First, the accusations against Governor 
Cook concern private, out-of-office conduct that was either known or knowable by 
the Executive and   Legislative   branches   in   considering   Governor   Cookโs   
nomination   and confirmation.  Second, Governor Cook has never been found guilty 
ofโor  even  been  formally  charged  withโany  wrongdoing.  Third,  even  the 
unsubstantiated accusations against Governor Cook are vague and incompleteโ
indeed, the government concedes (Mot. 1) that it does not know Governor Cookโs 
โmens  rea  when  making  the  representationsโ  at  issue.    Fourth,  the  President 
purported to terminate Governor Cook only after expressing disagreement with her 
policy views. 
Even setting aside the weakness of its position on the merits, the government 
cannot meet its burden, as a proponent of a stay, to show that the traditional equitable 
2 
 

stay factors favor its requested relief. Unlike the plaintiffs in other recent removal 
cases before this Court, Governor Cook has continued to serve in her position while 
her lawsuit is pending.  
A stay by this Court would therefore be the first signal from the courts that 
our system of government is no longer able to guarantee the independence of the 
Federal Reserve. Nothing would then stop the President from firing other members 
of the Board on similarly flimsy pretexts. The era of Fed independence would be 
over. 
The risks to the nationโs economy could be dire.  Central banks like the 
Federal Reserve are independent for a reason: Even the perception of political 
influence can destroy the investor confidence that is essential for economic growth 
and stability.  And that bell cannot be unrung.  Once confidence in the bankโs 
independence is lost, it cannot easily be regained.  The result, as the experience of 
other countries has shown, is spiraling interest rates and economic disaster.  The 
government  presents  no  interest  sufficient  to  justify  imposing  potentially  dire 
consequences on the national economy by rushing to grant relief that cannot be 
undone.  This Court should affirm the decision of the district court and consider this 
case on the merits in an orderly manner that fully preserves the status quo.   
STATEMENT OF THE CASE 
In 1913, Congress passed the Federal Reserve Act, 12 U.S.C. ยง 242. As 
3 
 

originally enacted, the FRA provided that Federal Reserve Board members could be 
removed by the President only โfor cause.โ  Id.  That for-cause removal provision 
was briefly rescinded after the Supreme Courtโs decision in Myers v. United States, 
272 U.S. 52 (1926), then reinstated less than a decade later.  
  Governor Cook is serving a 14-year term set to expire in 2038.  On August 
20, 2025, Federal Housing Finance Agency (โFHFAโ) Director Pulte posted on X a 
screenshot of a referral letter to the Department of Justice alleging that Governor 
Cook โappearsโ to have claimed two different homes as her main residence in 2021 
to โpotentiallyโ get lower interest rates and better loan terms. Though the referral 
letter was dated five days earlier, neither the FHFA nor the DOJ had given Governor 
Cook notice of the allegation prior to Director Pulteโs social media post. Just thirty 
minutes after Director Pulte posted on X, President Trump posted on Truth Social: 
โGovernor Cook must resign, now!!!โ 
  Five days later, President Trump posted a two-page letter on Truth Social 
purporting to fire Governor Cook from the Board of Governors of the Federal 
Reserve,  โeffective  immediately,โ  relying  on  the  unsubstantiated  allegation  in 
Director Pulteโs letter.  Governor Cook was not provided any opportunity to address 
or correct the unsubstantiated claims leveled against her by Director Pulte and 
President Trump.1       
 
1 The governmentโs motion repeatedly mischaracterizes the Presidentโs stated basis 
4 
 

STANDARD OF REVIEW 
  A stay pending appeal is an โextraordinaryโ remedy.  Citizens for Resp. & 
Ethics in Washington v. FEC, 904 F.3d 1014, 1017 (D.C. Cir. 2018) (per curiam).  
As the movant, the government must show (1) โstrongโ likelihood of success, (2) 
irreparable injury, (3) that a stay will not โsubstantially injure the other parties,โ and 
(4) that a stay favors the public interest.  See Nken v. Holder, 556 U.S. 418, 426 
(2009).  
I.  The  Presidentโs  โCauseโ  Determination  is  Subject  to  Judicial 
Review.  
The governmentโs motion begins (at 9) with a sweeping argument: that no 
court may review the Presidentโs โfor causeโ determination here.  But in Wiener v. 
United States, 357 U.S. 349 (1958), the Supreme Court had no difficulty recognizing 
the  availability  of  judicial  review  for  implied  for-cause  removals.   Id.  at  356 
(rejecting the claim that for-cause removal permits a President to remove an officer 
โmerely because he wanted his own appointeesโ).  If that is true, it must undoubtedly 
be true for express for-cause removals as well.  See Op. at 12 (explaining that 
 
for attempting to remove Governor Cook.  What began as purported termination for 
what โappearsโ as โgross negligenceโ and lack of โcompetence and trustworthinessโ 
(Compl. Ex. C) has turned into โevidence of apparent mortgage fraudโ (Mot. 5), 
โfinancial misconductโ (id. 11), and โfinancial fraudโ (id. 13, drawing analogies to 
Bernie Madoff, Charles Ponzi). The bases that the government offers for her removal 
now are not what the President claimed in the record.  And civil papers seeking 
emergency relief to preserve her job status are not the proper place to rebut the 
underlying and inaccurate accusations leveled against Governor Cook. 
5 
 

โwhether the President has even provided a legally permissible cause . . . is clearly 
reviewableโ).2   
Even so, the government insists that Reagan v. United States, 182 U.S. 419 
(1901) cuts against that view.  According to the government, when a statute permits 
โremoval for cause,โ that โโis a matter of discretion and not reviewable,โ at least if 
the โcauses are not definedโ by the statute.โ  ECF 13 at 7 (quoting Reagan, 182 U.S. 
at 425).  That is wrong.  
In  Reagan,  the  Supreme  Court  considered  whether  judicial  review  was 
available for certain judicially appointed commissioners without fixed tenure who 
were, under their authorizing statute, removable โfor causes prescribed by law.โ  Id. 
at 424.  It held that such commissioners were not entitled to judicial review.  Id. at 
425.  But in the course of deciding that question, the Court explicitly recognized that 
judicial  review  is  available  for  those  officers  (like  Federal  Reserve  Board 
Governors) serving fixed terms.  Id. at 425.  The Court specified that judicial review 
was available where โcauses of removal are specified by Constitution or statute, as 
also where the term of office is for a fixed period.โ  Id.  Reagan explained that, for 
 
2 Although the district court found it declined to inquire into the sufficiency of the 
evidence presented by the President because his โstated cause falls outside the causes 
permissible under the statute,โ Op. at 12 n.9, the sufficiency of evidence is subject 
to judicial review.  If it were not, the President could remove members of the Board 
by baselessly accusing them of whatever crimes he invented, so long as those crimes 
related to in-office conduct. 
6 
 

officers serving under a โfixed periodโ term of office, โnotice and hearing are 
essential. If there were not, the appointing power could remove at pleasure or for 
such cause as it deemed sufficient.โ  Id.  Reagan thus forecloses the governmentโs 
contention that under the FRA, a โcauseโ determination must be left to the President 
and President alone. 
That understanding dates back centuries. Lev Menand & Jane Manners, The 
Three  Permissions:  Presidential  Removal  and  the  Statutory  Limits  of  Agency 
Independence, 121 Colum. L. Rev. 1, 5 (2021) (โSince before the Founding, offices 
held for a term of years, in the absence of constitutional or statutory language to the 
contrary, were designed to be inviolable.โ).  And, were there any doubt, Marbury v. 
Madison โemphaticallyโ made this clear. 5 U.S. (1 Cranch) 137, 163 (1803) (holding 
that judicial  review is available  to  adjudicate  a fixed-tenured  officerโs  right to 
office). 
  Wiener also disposes of the governmentโs reliance on the ultra vires standard 
as requiring Cook to demonstrate that the president acted โcontrary to a specific 
prohibition  in  the  statute.โ    Mot.  at  10  (internal  quotations  and  citations 
omitted).  Weiner establishes that for-cause removal does not permit a President to 
remove an officer โmerely because he wanted his own appointees.โ  357 U.S. at 
356.   If  the  Court  could  review  that  contention,  it  can  review  this  one.    The 
government further errs in urgingโfor the first time on appealโthe applicability of 
7 
 

the โclear and mandatoryโ standard of Changji Esquel Textile Co. v. Raimondo, 40 
F.4th 716, 722 (D.C. Cir. 2022).  That standard applies where there is a โstatutory 
preclusion of review.โ  Id.  The government makes no such claim here, and this 
Court has long rejected the governmentโs argument โthat there are no judicially 
enforceable limitations on presidential actions, besides actions that run afoul of the 
Constitution  or  which  contravene  direct  statutory  prohibitions,  so  long  as  the 
President claims that he is acting pursuant toโ a statute.  Chamber of Commerce of 
U.S. v. Reich, 74 F.3d 1322, 1332 (D.C. Cir. 1996).  
II.  The is Government is Not Likely to Succeed on the Merits 
A.  โFor Causeโ Does Not Mean โAt Will.โ 
  The  governmentโs  interpretation  of  โfor  causeโ  removal  would  turn  the 
Federal Reserve into an at-will body.  That position is flawed as a statutory matter: 
โโfor causeโ does not mean the same thing as โat will.โโ  Collins v. Yellen, 594 U.S. 
220, 256 (2021) (alteration adopted).  And it fails to appreciate the Federal Reserveโs 
status as a โuniquely structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the distinct 
historical tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States.โ  Trump v. 
Wilcox, 145 S. Ct. 1415, 1415 (2025).   
B.  The  Presidentโs  Attempt  to  Remove  Governor  Cook  was 
Without โCauseโ 
1.  The District Court Correctly Concluded that Pre-
Office Conduct Does Not Constitute Cause. 
The government insists that Governor Cookโs allegedly wrongful conduct 
8 
 

prior to taking office satisfies the for cause removal standard. But the historical 
meaning of โfor causeโ belies that argument.  โFor causeโ removal protection has 
long been anchored to โthe Humphreyโs Executor standard of โinefficiency, neglect 
of duty, or malfeasance in office.โโ  Free Enterprise Fund v. Public Co. Accounting 
Oversight Board, 561 U.S. 477, 487 (2010).  While considering the 1935 amendment 
that reinstated โfor causeโ removal protection for Board Governors, Congress made 
the affirmative decision to wait for the Supreme Courtโs decision in Humphreyโs 
Executor before finalizing the language of the act.  See Gary Richardson & David 
W. Wilcox, How Congress Designed the Federal Reserve to be Independent of 
Presidential Control, 39 J. of Econ. Perspectives 3, 229 (2025).  
In May 1935, the Court published Humphreyโs Executor, which confirmed the 
constitutionality of inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office (โINMโ) 
removal restrictions, expressly holding that Congress had the authority to โforbid 
the[] removalโ of certain officers by the President โexcept for cause.โ 295 U.S. at 
629 (emphasis added).  Three months later, Congress passed the Banking Act of 
1935 to provide that the President could not remove Board members except โfor 
cause.โ  12 U.S.C. ยง 242.  Congress used โfor causeโ rather than โINMโ to restore 
the 1913 language of the FRA, which took for granted that โfor causeโ meant INM. 
  Apart from INM, no other statutorily enumerated grounds for presidential 
removal of executive officers existed in the U.S. Code at the time of the FRAโs 
9 
 

enactment in 1913.  Today, other provisions of the U.S. Code contain specific 
grounds  for  presidential  removal  of  government  officials,  but  those  additional 
grounds for removal were not statutorily enumerated at the time of the FRAโs 
original enactment, and they cannot be incorporated after-the-fact into the statute.  
In  1935,  the  only  statutorily  enumerated  grounds  for  presidential  removal  of 
executive officers were INM (see Manners & Menand, 121 Colum. L. Rev. at 72โ
73 app. A, B), confirming that Congress intended removal โfor causeโ to be limited 
to that standard.    
To the extent that removal โfor causeโ extends beyond INM, the district court 
correctly held that such grounds must be โin-office conduct that is closely related to 
the INM grounds.โ  Op. at 19.  The canonical English case Rex v. Richardson, 1 
Burrows, 517, 538 (1758), informed American courtsโ view about what category of 
non-office (including pre-office) conduct amounted to removable cause at the time 
of the FRAโs enactment.  That category of offenses was vanishingly small.  It 
included only misconduct โ(1) Such as have no immediate relation to his office, but 
are in themselves of so infamous a nature, as to render the offender unfit to execute 
any public franchise.โ State ex rel. Atty. Gen. v. McLain, 58 Ohio St. 313, 320 (1898) 
(quoting Rex v. Richardson, 1 Burrows at 538) (emphasis added).  In the decades 
surrounding the FRAโs enactment, no fewer than eight state supreme courts cited 
10 
 

Rex v. Richardson in defining removable cause.3   
  The government asserts โthe district court had no problem confirming that the 
President would have cause to remove Cook if she was convicted of mortgage fraud 
based on her conduct before taking officeโ and insists โcriminal conviction is not a 
prerequisite for removal under 12 U.S.C. ยง 242.โ  Mot. at 2.  But the district court 
did  not  suggest  that  conviction  was  a  prerequisite  for  removal  nor  was  it 
contradicting its pre- versus post-office distinction.  What the district court correctly 
noted was that โwhere an officer is convicted of a serious crime and incarcerated 
while in office . . . [s]uch a conviction would obviously interfere with the ability of 
an officer to effectively and faithfully carry out their in-office duties,โ or in other 
words, neglect of duty.  Op. at 21โ22 (emphasis added).4    
C.  Governor  Cook  Was  Deprived  of  Her  Statutory  and 
Constitutional Rights to Notice and an Opportunity to Be 
Heard.  
  Even assuming that the Presidentโs stated reasons could satisfy the โfor causeโ 
standard, his purported firing of Governor Cook would still be unlawful. That is 
 
3 See id.; ECF 17 at 12 (collecting cases).  
4 Instead of looking to the history, statutory context and precedent establishing โfor 
causeโ protection as a term of art anchored to the โinefficiency, neglect of duty, or 
malfeasance  in  officeโ  standard  established  in  Humphreyโs  Executor,  the 
government continues to rely exclusively on dictionary definitions to advance its 
preferred reading of โcause.โ  That interpretive approach is incorrect, and as the 
district court pointed out, it even fails on its own terms.  See Op. at 9โ10.  
11 
 

because Governor Cook was deprived of her statutory right to notice and a hearing 
under both the FRA and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. 
  The district court did not evaluate whether the FRAโs for-cause removal 
provision afforded Governor Cook the right to notice and a hearing, as it concluded 
that the Due Process Clause provided an independent source of that right. But the 
Supreme Court has made clear that for-cause removal provisions like the FRAโs 
establish a statutory right to notice and a hearing before an official may be removed.   
  The critical cases are Reagan and Shurtleff v. United States, 189 U.S. 311 
(1903).  Reagan recognized a โruleโ that โwhere causes of removal are specified by 
constitution or statute, as also where the term of office is for a fixed period, notice 
and hearing are essential.โ  182 U.S. at 425.  Shurtleff reiterated that rule, writing (in 
the context of an INM statute) that โif the removal is sought to be made for those 
causes, or either of them, the officer is entitled to notice and a hearing.โ  189 U.S. at 
314.5   
Together, Shurtleff and Reagan require notice and a hearing when a President 
seeks to remove an official with for-cause-removal protections.  The governmentโs 
 
5 Both Reagan and Shurtleff involved statutes dealing with federal officers, not 
employees, and the officer in Shurtleff was a principal officer.  No hearing was 
necessary in Reagan because Congress had not specified any causes, see supra 
Section I.A, or in Shurtleff because the Court held that the officer, who had no fixed 
term, could be removed for causes other than those specified in the statute, see 189 
U.S. at 317.   
12 
 

attempt to rewrite this โwell-settledโ rule fails.  PHH Corp. v. CFPB, 881 F.3d 75, 
135 (D.C. Cir. 2018) (Griffith, J., concurring) (citing Reagan and Shurtleff).  The 
government asserts that one has no statutory right to notice and a hearing unless 
those specific protections are โvery clear and explicit,โ and that Governor Cook is 
not entitled to notice and a hearing because the FRA does not use the words โnotice 
and a hearing.โ  ECF 13 at 19.  But neither did the statutes in Shurtleff or Reagan, 
and so the governmentโs distinction of those cases is no distinction at all.      
The same conclusion follows from the Due Process Clause.  As an officer with 
for-cause removal protection, Governor Cook has a property interest in her position.  
โA  property  interest  exists  if  the  employee  can  be  removed  only  for  cause.โ 
Esparraguera v. Depโt of the Army, 101 F.4th 28, 33 (D.C. Cir. 2024) (citations and 
quotations  omitted).  The  Governmentโs  sole  response  is  to  claim  that  because 
Governor Cook is an officer of the United States, not โa mere public employee,โ she 
โha[s] no property interest in her public office and was thus owed no notice or 
opportunity to be heard.โ  Mot. at 18.  But no case the government cites comes close 
to recognizing that distinction.  
First, the governmentโs theory is foreclosed by the foundational precedent of 
Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. (1 Cranch) 137 (1803).  Marbury, which considered the 
validity  of  William Marburyโs appointment as justice  of the  peaceโan  officer 
position requiring Presidential appointment and Senate confirmation makes plain 
13 
 

that the critical distinction regarding a property right is whether the holder of a 
position serves at will, not whether she is an officer or employee.  As Chief Justice 
Marshall explained:  
[W]hen the officer is not removable at the will of the executive, the 
appointment is not revocable, and cannot be annulled. It has conferred 
legal rights which cannot be resumed.  
 
Id. at 162 (emphases added).  
The cases the government cites in support of its proposed โofficer/employeeโ 
distinction lend no support to its theory.  Rather, those cases stand for the proposition 
that โneither the tenure nor salary of federal officers is constitutionally protected 
from impairment by Congress.โ Glidden Co. v. Zdanok, 370 U.S. 530, 534 (1962) 
(emphasis added).  That conclusion is entirely consistent with the notion that PAS 
officers with for-cause removal protection enjoy a property interest in their positions.  
As the Court put it in Cleveland Board of Education v. Loudermill, โproperty 
interests are not created by the Constitution, they are created and their dimensions 
are defined by existing rules or understandings that stem from an independent 
sourceโ such as a statute.  470 U.S. 532, 538 (1985) (internal citation and quotation 
marks omitted).  The โstatute . . . creates such an interest.โ  Id.  Thus, by repealing 
or amending the very statute that gives rise to a property rightโhere, the Federal 
Reserve Actโa legislature could eliminate that right.  But the Fifth Amendment 
prevents the President from unilaterally terminating a property right conferred by 
14 
 

statute.  
The governmentโs other cases are even further afield.  Crenshaw v. United 
States  held  only  that  an  employeeโa  cadet  midshipman  without  โfor  causeโ 
removal protectionโlacked โany vested interest or contract right in his office of 
which congress could not deprive him.โ  134 U.S. 99, 104 (1890) (emphasis added).  
Crenshaw is thus inapposite for multiple reasons.  Taylor v. Beckham, 178 US 548 
(1900), and Baker v. Carr, 369 US 186 (1962), considered whether candidates for 
elected officeโnot PAS officers with for-cause removal protectionsโhad a property 
right to โpublic office.โ  Baker, 369 U.S. at 232.  Governor Cook is not a losing 
candidate for office; she is a public official protected by removal only for cause.   
  Governor Cook was deprived of a forum in which to offer any evidence.  The 
government seems to blame her for that shortcoming, stating she never โsought to 
offer any evidence . . . that would explain her actions.โ  Mot. at 19.  It cannot be the 
case that deprivation of due process is harmless unless the person informally raises 
her arguments ahead of the proceeding to which she is entitled.6 
III.  The Remaining Factors Favor Governor Cook.  
 
6 The complete property records reveal the opposite. See, e.g., Fed Governor Lisa 
Cook claimed 2nd residence as โvacation home,โ undercutting Trump fraud claims, 
Assoc. Press (Sept. 12, 2025), https://apnews.com/article/federal-reserve-lisa-cook-
trump-852820c83e5001ec3b6e2d14047965c9 (affirming, based on the review of 
bank documents, that Governor Cook designated her Atlanta property for use as a 
โVacation Homeโ). 
15 
 

  The  Federal  Reserveโs  independenceโeven  and  especially  from  the 
Presidentโis a result of intentional Congressional design, the wisdom of which has 
borne  out  over  decades.    The  governmentโs  argument  challenges  all  of  that, 
threatening the stability and predictability of economic markets worldwide.7  The 
equitable factors weigh heavily against a stay, which would undermine more than a 
century of the Federal Reserveโs independence and have dire repercussions for the 
economy.  
  As  Justice  Kavanaugh  previously  observed,  it  โmay  be  worthwhile  to 
insulateโ the Board โfrom direct presidential oversight or controlโ because of the 
Boardโs โpower to directly affect the short-term functioning of the U.S. economy by 
setting interest rates and adjusting the money supply.โ  Separation of Powers During 
the Forty-Fourth Presidency and Beyond, 93 Minn. L. Rev. 1454, 1474 (2009).  The 
publicโs โbelie[f] that the central bank is free from interference and that the law 
[governing the bank] is unlikely to change swiftlyโ is crucial for ensuring economic 
stability.  Cristina  Bodea  &  Raymond  Hicks,  Price  Stability  and  Central  Bank 
Independence, 69 Intโl Orgs. 35, 38 (2015). 
 
7 โEven the perception that monetary-policy decisions are politically motivated, or 
influenced by threats that policy makers wonโt be able to serve out their terms of 
office, can undermine public confidence . . .โ Paul Volcker, Alan Greenspan, Ben 
Bernanke & Janet Yellen, America Needs an Independent Fed, Wall St. J. (Aug. 5, 
2019),  https://www.wsj.com/articles/america-needs-an-independent-fed-
11565045308.  
16 
 

  The governmentโs argument threatens that.  Granting a stay (allowing the 
removal  of  Governor  Cook)  would  harm  Congress,  which  โhas  an  interest  in 
ensuring that Federal Reserve Board members are removed for only statutorily 
permitted reasons, and preventing the President from thwarting the very ends which 
Congress sought to realize by definitively fixing the term of office.โ  Op. at 47 
(internal quotation marks and alterations removed).  It would harm the public, which 
has an interest in requiring the executive branch to โabide by the federal laws that 
govern their existence and operations.โ  League of Women Voters of United States 
v. Newby, 838 F.3d 1, 12 (D.C. Cir. 2016).  And as economists have warned, 
everyday  Americans  ultimately  would  pay  the  price:  higher  prices  โvia  higher 
inflation and higher interest ratesโ that result โwhen central bank independence is 
lost.โ8 
  Those profound risks to the financial markets are imminent. At all times 
during this litigation, Governor Cook has been performing her duties as a duly 
nominated and confirmed member of the Board. Critically, Governor Cookโs duties 
have  included  preparing  for  next  weekโs  Federal  Open  Market  Committee 
(โFOMCโ) policy meeting, at which she and other FOMC members will review the 
Federal Reserveโs monetary policy, issue statements on market outlook, and vote on 
 
8 Ian Smith, Emily Herbert & Kate Duguid, Donald Trumpโs Attack on Fed Shifts 
Market  Bets  on  Interest  Rates  and  Inflation,  Fin.  Times  (Aug.  26,  2025), 
https://www.ft.com/content/d8a8d068-18ba-4e29-a69f-6c155ffc67f3. 
17 
 

setting interest rates.  A stay pending appeal would threaten Governor Cookโs 
participation in next weekโs meeting and potentially plunge the FOMCโs operations 
into turmoil.  The government offers no justification to explain why this Court 
should sanction such a severe disruption of the status quo.  
  The government spares only a sentence to acknowledge the catastrophic effect 
that undermining the independence of the Federal Reserve Board is sure to have on 
the economy.  Mot. at 23.  But the governmentโs failure to acknowledge the problem 
will not make it go away.  Over the past several months, as President Trump has 
threatened the Federal Reserveโs independence, markets have reacted quickly and 
sharply.9  Throughout this litigation, Governor Cook has continued to serve in her 
role, so a grant of a stay from this Court would be the first signal from the courts that 
her  removal  may  be  lawful.    This  Courtโs  interventionโparticularly  before  it 
carefully  considers  the  merits  of  the  governmentโs  argument  and  all  of  its 
repercussionsโwould thus cause needless confusion in a sensitive economic area.  
And once the credibility of the Federal Reserve as an independent body is damaged, 
it will not easily be restored. 
  In claiming that it would be irreparably injured if it does not receive a stay 
 
9 See Polo Rocha, Trumpโs Criticism of Powell Is Shaking Marketsโ Faith in Fedโs 
Independence, Investopedia (Apr. 21, 2025), https://www.investopedia.com/trump-
criticism-of-powell-is-shaking-markets-faith-in-federal-reserve-independence-
11719211. 
18 
 

here, the government relies exclusively (Mot. at 20) on cases involving officials 
whom  the  President  asserts he has unilateral power  to  remove.    But here,  the 
government expressly disclaims any such constitutional argument.  Mot. at 4โ5.  The 
government cannot and does not explain why the President is irreparably harmed 
here when the Federal Reserve continues to operateโas Congress intendedโfree 
from direct presidential control.  The governmentโs irreparable harm arguments 
merely reinforce the Presidentโs desire to change policy at the Federal Reserve by 
effectuating the removal in an emergency litigation posture. 
   In particular, the governmentโs reliance on Trump v. Boyle, 145 S. Ct. 2653 
(2025) and Trump v. Wilcox is misplaced.  Though the factors in those cases weighed 
in  favor  of  the  government,  the  Supreme  Court  specifically  disclaimed  the 
applicability of those cases to this one.  The Court acknowledged that โ[t]he Federal 
Reserve is a uniquely structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the distinct 
historical tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States,โ unlike the 
Consumer Product  Safety  Commission or  the  National Labor  Relations  Board.  
Wilcox, 145 S. Ct. at 1415.  The Court explained further that its decision in Wilcox 
did not โimplicate the constitutionality of for-cause removal protections for members 
of the Federal Reserveโs Board of Governors.โ  Id.  And it followed that statement 
by warning lower courts that โinterim ordersโ like the one issued in Wilcox tell lower 
courts how they โshould exercise [their] equitable discretion.โ  Boyle, 145 S. Ct. at 
19 
 

2654.10  Taking those statements together can only mean thatโgiven the Federal 
Reserveโs historical independenceโthe stay factors cash out differently when it 
comes to the removal of a Federal Reserve Board member than they did in Wilcox 
and Boyle.   
Nor can the government successfully argue that Governor Cook would not be 
irreparably harmed by her removal from the Board.  Indeed, the governmentโs claim 
that it needs relief in advance of the September 16 FOMC meeting (Mot. at 4) cannot 
be squared with its assertion that Governor Cook has no โclear and present needโ 
(Mot. at 22) to participate as a duly appointed governor of the Federal Reserve 
Board.  The very fact of that meeting confirms that even a temporary absence from 
the Board would irreparably injure Governor Cookโs ability to participate as a 
governor.  See Sampson v. Murray, 415 U.S. 61, 92 n.68 (1974).  And to be clear, 
Governor Cook is not asking to be reinstatedโshe has been continuously serving in 
her Senate-confirmed role.  Moreover, President Trump has made clear that he 
intends to and can fill Governor Cookโs seat by the time even an expedited resolution 
of this case could occur.  If a stay is granted, there may be no seat to which Governor 
 
10 The governmentโs suggestion (Mot. at 20 n.2) that courts lack equitable authority 
to โreinstate[]โ Governor Cook cannot be squared with the general rule that, when 
courts find a presidential action unlawful, they can โenjoin the officers who attempt 
to enforce the Presidentโs directive.โ  Franklin v. Massachusetts, 505 U.S. 788, 828 
(1992) (Scalia, J., concurring in part and concurring in the judgment).  And, again, 
Governor Cook has remained in office and the governmentโs motion seeks to change 
that.  
20 
 

Cook  could  return  if  she  prevails  on  the  meritsโfurther  demonstrating  the 
irreparable harm she faces.   
  The government also fails to offer any sort of stopping point or limiting 
principle to its argument. If this Court accepts the governmentโs argument, the 
President would be given the power to make unsubstantiated charges for any type of 
alleged misconduct to remove any other member of the Board.  At a time when the 
President is publicly pressuring the Chair of the Federal Reserve to adopt his favored 
monetary policy, any signal from the courts that the Federal Reserveโs independence 
is in jeopardy risks unsettling markets. This moment calls for orderly process and 
sober deliberationโnot a destabilizing rush to judgment. 
CONCLUSION 
  For the foregoing reasons, Appellantโs motion should be denied.

INTRODUCTION  
  Federal Reserve Board Governor Lisa D. Cook seeks an emergency temporary restraining 
order  to  prevent  implementation  of  President  Trumpโs  August  25,  2025  Truth  Social  post 
unlawfully purporting to remove her from her position as a Federal Reserve Board Governor.  The 
Presidentโs effort to terminate a Senate-confirmed Federal Reserve Board member is a broadside 
attack on the century-old independence of the Federal Reserve System. As one editorial described, 
it represents a blatant โgrab for power in defiance of the nationโs laws, and if it succeeds, it will be 
to the detriment of the nationโs interests.โ2 
  Governor Cook is likely to succeed on the merits of her claims that President Trumpโs 
purported firing violated her statutory and constitutional rights.  If the Presidentโs unlawful decree 
were allowed to stand, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System would be forced to 
effectuate President Trumpโs unlawful attempted termination of Governor Cook, in violation of 
both the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. ยง 242) and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth 
Amendment.  Governor Cook will succeed at showing irreparable harm, as President Trumpโs 
unprecedented actions threaten her Senate-confirmed position on the Board, and her ability to 
fulfill her duty to promote maximum employment and price stability.  Finally, the equities and 
public interest both weigh in favor of keeping Governor Cook in her position, as her purported 
firing would jeopardize the independence of the Federal Reserve, and ultimately, the stability of 
our nationโs financial system.   
Accordingly, Governor Cook moves for an immediate TRO (1) declaring that President 
Trumpโs August 25, 2025 attempted firing of Governor Cook is unlawful under the Federal 
Reserve Act and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment, and that Governor Cook is still 
 
2  Editorial,  Whereโs  Your  Evidence,  Mr.  President?,  N.Y.  Times  (Aug.  27,  2025), 
https://www.nytimes.com/2025/08/26/opinion/politics/trump-fed-independence-lisa-cook.html.  
1 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 6 of 28
a member of the Federal Reserve Board; and (2) enjoining Defendants the Federal Reserve Board 
of Governors, collectively and/or individually, and Chairman Jerome Powell from effectuating in 
any manner the illegal purported removal of Governor Cook from her position or in any way 
treating her as having been removed, or denying or obstructing her in accessing any of the benefits 
or resources of her Board position.  
BACKGROUND 
I.  The Structure and History of the Federal Reserve Act Illustrate the Importance 
of the Independence of the Federal Reserve.  
  The Federal Reserve System was established by the Federal Reserve Act (โFRAโ) in 1913 
to provide the nation with a safer, more flexible, and more stable monetary and financial system.  
As articulated by the Supreme Court in Trump v. Wilcox, โ[t]he Federal Reserve is a uniquely 
structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the distinct historical tradition of the First and 
Second Banks of the United States.โ  145 S. Ct. 1415, 1415 (May 22, 2025) (citing Seila Law LLC 
v. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, 591 U.S. 197, 222 n.8 (2020)).  The intent that the 
Federal Reserve retain independence has been reinforced by statutory amendments to the FRA in 
1935, 1977, and 2010. 
The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve is the seven-member governing body of 
the Federal Reserve Systemโmade up of the chairperson plus six Governorsโresponsible for 
setting monetary policy, supervising and regulating banks, and maintaining financial stability. The 
Governors, who are appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate, serve staggered 14-
year terms.  The long and staggered term procedure reinforces the independence of the Board. 
An independent and credible Federal Reserve is essential for a stable economy, as the short-
term political interests of a president often clash with sound monetary policy.  An independent 
central bank acts predictably and transparently, which stabilizes markets and the wider economy. 
2 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 7 of 28
A politically insulated Board of Governors can make appropriate, albeit unpopular, decisionsโ
such as raising interest rates to combat inflationโthat are crucial for the nationโs long-term 
financial health. 
The independence of the Federal Reserve is supported by several statutory provisions that 
shield the Board of Governors from political interference.  Such statutory provisions intended to 
insulate the Board of Governors from outside influence include: the Boardโs funding outside the 
annual appropriations process;3 the Boardโs authority to set all terms and conditions of Board 
employment;4 the  Boardโs  exemption  from  Government  Accountability  Office  audits  of  its 
monetary policy decisions;5 the Boardโs authority to litigate independently;6 the Boardโs ability to 
present  legislative  recommendations  and  testimony  to  Congress  without  executive  branch 
approval;7 the exemption of the Boardโs monetary policy decisions from the Congressional Review 
Act;8 and the Boardโs authorization to participate directly in certain international fora without 
executive branch intermediation.9

4 12 U.S.C. ยง 244. 
5 See, e.g., 12 U.S.C. ยง 3910 (exempting from GAO audits of the Board and Reserve Banks, inter

direction of the FOMC, or transactions with foreign central banks); 31 U.S.C. ยง 714(b) (same).

note.

II.  The Federal Reserve Actโs โFor Causeโ Removal Provision Protects the 
Independence of the Board of Governors.  
The crucial independence of the Board of Governors is guarded by the Federal Reserve 
Actโs โfor causeโ removal provision, which prevents the President from firing a Governor except 
for instances of inefficiency, neglect of duty, malfeasance in office, or comparable conduct.  The 
FRA expressly provides that 
Upon the expiration of the term of any appointive member of the Federal 
Reserve Board in office on August 23, 1935, the President shall fix the term

for cause.โโ) (quoting Thompson v. District of Columbia, 530 F.3d 914, 918 (D.C. Cir. 2008)).  
Because Governor Cook possesses a property interest in her position on the Board, the Due 
Process Clause guarantees that she cannot be removed withoutโat a minimumโโoral or written 
notice of the charges against [her], an explanation of the employerโs evidence, and an opportunity 
to present [her] side of the story.โ  Loudermill, 470 U.S. at 546.  And critically, both the Supreme 
Court and D.C. Circuit have instructed that any such hearing must take place โprior to the 
discharge of an employee.โ  Loudermill, 470 U.S. at 542 (emphasis added); Esparraguera, 101 
F.4th at 40 (โOur cases are clear that, absent exigent circumstances not implicated here, the Due 
Process Clause requires, at minimum, that the government provide notice and some kind of hearing 
before final deprivation of a property interest.โ) (internal citation and quotation marks omitted) 
(emphasis in original). 
Governor Cook received neither notice nor a hearing before her purported โfiring.โ Instead, 
she found out about the attempt to remove her through President Trumpโs Truth Social post, which 
contained a letter addressed to Governor Cook stating that โyou are hereby removed from your 
position on the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve, effective immediatelyโ24 (emphasis 
added).  Regardless of the factual basis underpinning the attempt to remove an employee with for 
 
24  Donald  J.  Trump  (@realDonaldTrump),  Truth  Social  (Aug.  25,  2025,  8:02  PM), 
https://truthsocial.com/@realDonaldTrump/posts/115092130707196133.  
16 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 21 of 28
cause protection (and here, there is nothing more than an unsubstantiated allegation that Governor 
Cook filled out a form incorrectly), the Supreme Court has explained that 
Some opportunity for the employee to present [her] side of the case is recurringly 
of obvious value in reaching an accurate decision. . . . Even where the facts are 
clear, the appropriateness or necessity of the discharge may not be; in such cases, 
the only meaningful opportunity to invoke the discretion of the decisionmaker is 
likely to be before the termination takes effect. 
 
Loudermill, 470 U.S. at 543 (internal citations omitted).  Governor Cook was never afforded notice 
or the opportunity to present her side of the case.  She was therefore deprived of her constitutional 
right to due process under the Fifth Amendment.  
  Governor Cookโs purported termination without notice and a hearing also violated her 
statutory rights to these same protections under the FRA.  The Supreme Court has recognized that 
โfor causeโ removal protections also create a statutory right to notice and a hearing.  See Reagan 
v. United States, 182 U.S. 419, 425 (1901) (โ[W]here the term of office is for a fixed period, notice 
and hearing are essential.โ); Shurtleff v. United States, 189 U.S. 311, 314 (1903) (โIt must be 
presumed that the President did not make the removal for any cause assigned in the statute, because 
there was given to the officer no notice or opportunity to defend.โ).  The Presidentโs attempt to 
remove Governor Cook violates the procedural protections of the FRA, as the statuteโs inclusion 
of โfor causeโ removal protectionโa term of artโconferred in Governor Cook a statutory right to 
notice and a hearing.  The President attempted to terminate her without even the pretense of either.   
II.  Governor Cook Will Suffer Irreparable Harm Absent Relief. 
Emergency relief is necessary because, without it, Governor Cook is at the threshold of 
suffering  irreparable  injury  from  Defendantsโ  conductโdepriving  her  of  her  Presidentially-
appointed and Senate-confirmed role as a Federal Reserve Board Governor.  See Berry v. Reagan, 
1983 WL 538, at *5 (D.D.C. Nov. 14, 1983), vacated as moot, 732 F.2d 949 (D.C. Cir. 1983).  
Further highlighting the irreparable nature of Governor Cookโs harm, during a Cabinet meeting on 
17 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 22 of 28
August 26, 2025, President Trump said he has already named a group of candidates to replace 
her.25  Without emergency relief, Defendants are now likely to allow an unexpired vacancy to 
occur for which President Trump has indicated he is ready to fill.   
President Trumpโs unlawful attempt to remove Governor Cook will also cause irreparable 
harm to her efforts as Governor to preserve the independence of the Federal Reserve Board.  See 
Albrecht v. Comm. on Emp. Benefits of Fed. Reserve Emp. Benefits Sys., 357 F.3d 62, 67 (D.C. 
Cir. 2004) (โAn integral part of the federal government, the Board conducts monetary policy, 
regulates  banking  institutions,  and maintains the stability of  the  nation's  financial system.โ).   
President Trump is already touting that the Federal Reserve Board โwill have a majority very 
shortlyโ of members he has selected.26   President Trumpโs statements and actions are undermining 
the publicโs perception of the Federal Reserve as independent, directly threatening its mission of 
providing stability.  As the Supreme Court recognized in Humphreyโs Executor, the โcoercive 
influence of [at-will removal power] threatens the independence of a commission.โ  295 U.S. at 
630.   Governor Cook was duty-sworn to maintain that independence.  
To demonstrate irreparable harm, a moving party must satisfy two requirements.  Radio 
Free Europe/Radio Liberty, Inc. v. Lake, 772 F. Supp. 3d 79, 85 (D.D.C. 2025). โFirst, the harm 
must be certain and great, actual and not theoretical, and so imminen[t] that there is a clear and 
present need for equitable relief to prevent irreparable harm.โ  Id. (citations and quotation marks 
omitted).  โSecond, the harm must be beyond remediation.โ  Id. (citations and quotation marks 
omitted).  Here, as in Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, Inc., the harm movant currently faces is 
โgreat, actual and not theoreticalโ and is exceedingly imminent.  Id.

02:32 (Aug. 26, 2025), https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cbEPqUdelFo.

18 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 23 of 28
This Court has repeatedly โrecognized irreparable harm in similar cases โinvolving the 
removal of individuals appointed to independent, multimember boards based on the[ir] unlawful 
removal from office by the President and the obviously disruptive effect that such removal has on 
the organizationโs functioning.โโ  Harper v. Bessent, 2025 WL 2049207, at *13 (D.D.C. July 22, 
2025) (quoting LeBlanc v. U.S. Priv. & Civ. Lib. Oversight Bd., 2025 WL 1454010, at *30 (D.D.C. 
May 21, 2025)) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).  Irreparable harm in cases of 
removal of individuals appointed to independent boards is based on โthe[ir] โunlawful removal 
from office by the Presidentโ and โthe obviously disruptive effectโ that such removal has on the 
organizationโs functioning.โ  Wilcox v. Trump, 775 F. Supp. 3d 215, 235 (D.D.C. Mar. 6, 2025) 
(quoting Berry, 1983 WL 538, at *5); see LeBlanc, 2025 WL 1454010, at *28โ33 (finding that 
plaintiffs had established irreparable harm via the threat of being removed as members of the U.S. 
Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board).  Here, President Trumpโs unlawful attempt to 
remove Governor Cook is causing her, and her ability to carry out her oath to protect the Federal 
Reserve, and subsequently, our nationโs economy, irreparable harm.   
III.  The Balance of the Equities and Public Interest Favor Governor Cook.  
The proper and independent functioning of the Federal Reserve Board, and the economic 
stability that it provides, is plainly in the public interest.  The Federal Reserve board โserve[s] the 
public interest by providing the nation with a stable financial situation and by setting and 
implementing monetary policy.โ  TNB USA Inc. v. Fed. Reserve Bank of N.Y., 2020 WL 1445806, 
at *1 (S.D.N.Y. Mar. 25, 2020) (internal citation omitted).  The D.C. Circuit has recognized the 
importance of the Federal Reserveโs independence: 
19 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 24 of 28
The  independence  of  financial  regulators  remains  a  prominent  pattern 
today. The Federal Reserve Board is led by governors who can be removed 
only for cause during their fourteen-year terms. 12 U.S.C. ยง 242. The reason 
is simple: The Federal Reserve must โprovide for the sound, effective, and 
uninterrupted operation of the banking system,โ and Congress found that a 
degree of independence was needed to โincrease the ability of the banking 
system  to  promote  stability.โ  H.R.  Rep.  No.  74-742,  at  1  (1935).  By 
insulating the Board from presidential control and political pressures, 
Congress sought to ensure that the Federal Reserve would โreflect, not the 
opinion of a majority of special interests, but rather the well considered 
judgment of a body that takes into consideration all phases of national 
economic life. 
PHH Corp. v. Consumer Fin. Prot. Bureau, 881 F.3d 75, 92 (D.C. Cir. 2018) (internal citation 
omitted) (emphasis added).  Here, President Trumpโs actions amount to the exact โpresidential 
control and political pressuresโ from which Congress intended to insulate the Board.  Id.  The 
public interest favors maintaining the very stability that the Federal Reserve was created to 
preserve, at least until the novel issues presented by Governor Cookโs attempted โfiringโ can be 
properly adjudicated.  
  The marketโs immediate reaction to President Trumpโs attempt to fire Governor Cook only 
underscores the strength of the publicโs interest in the Federal Reserve Boardโs independence. 
Shortly after President Trump announced his purported firing of Governor Cook, the dollar 
weakened against major currencies.27  Long-dated U.S. Treasuries also fell.28  As four former 
chairs of the Federal Reserve Board explained in a joint article in 2019: 
[R]esearch has shown that monetary policy based on the political (rather than 
economic) needs of the moment leads to worse economic performance in the long 
run,  including  higher  inflation  and  slower  growth.  Even  the  perception  that 
monetary-policy decisions are politically motivated, or influenced by threats that 
policy makers wonโt be able to serve out their terms of office, can undermine public 
 
27 See Laura Matthews & Jaspreet Kalra, Dollar Weakens As Trumpโs Move To Fire Fed Governor 
Spooks Investors, Reuters (Aug. 26, 2025), https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/dollar-
weakens-trumps-move-fire-fed-governor-spooks-investors-2025-08-26/. 
28 See Ruth Carson et al., Long US Bonds Fall as Threat to Fedโs Cook Spurs Inflation Worry, 
Bloomberg (Aug. 26, 2025), https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-08-26/dollar-falls-
with-treasuries-as-trump-seeks-to-oust-fed-s-cook.  
20 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 25 of 28
confidence that the central bank is acting in the best interest of the economy. That 
can lead to unstable financial markets and worse economic outcomes. 
 
Paul Volcker, Alan Greenspan, Ben Bernanke & Janet Yellen, America Needs an Independent 
Fed, Wall St. J. (Aug. 5, 2019), https://www.wsj.com/articles/america-needs-an-independent-fed-
11565045308.29  
  The publicโs interest in financial stability and economic prosperity is not the only interest 
weighing against the Presidentโs attempted firing of Governor Cook.   Another โpublic interestโ is 
protecting Congressโs express desire to maintain the Federal Reserve Boardโs independence.  As 
Justice Kagan recently articulated  
[T]he relevant interest is not the โwrongfully removed officer[sโ],โ but rather 
Congressโs and, more broadly, the publicโs. What matters, in other words, is not 
that [an officeholder] would love to keep serving in [her] nifty job[]. What matters 
instead is that Congress provided for [her] to serve [her] full term[], protected from 
a Presidentโs desire to substitute his political allies.  
 
Trump v. Wilcox, 145 S. Ct. at 1420 (Kagan, J., dissenting).  Through the Federal Reserve Act, 
Congress expressed its clear will that Federal Reserve Board members be free from political 
interference.  That is the interest that President Trumpโs attempted firing has imperiled. 
   The countervailing interest at stake, which President Trump seems to openly admit, is his 
desire to control the countryโs central bank.  But that has never been within the scope of the 
Presidentโs power.  โ[T]he Fedโs most important responsibility is administration of the money 
supply,โ (and resultingly, interest rates) and โunlike law enforcement, administration of the money 
supply is not an executive function โ so the Fedโs independence does not offend the traditional 
 
29 Additionally, several editorials published in U.S. newspapers since President Trumpโs August 
25 letter was released clearly support and demonstrate that relief for Governor Cook is in the public 
interest.  See, e.g., Editorial, Whereโs Your Evidence, Mr. President?, N.Y. Times (Aug. 26, 2025); 
Editorial, What if Trump Runs the Federal Reserve?, Wall St. J. (Aug. 26, 2025); Editorial, Here 
Are The Consequences Of A President Politicizing The Fed, Wash. Post (Aug. 26, 2025); see also 
Janet Yellen, Trumpโs Attack on the Fed Threatens US Credibility, Finan. Times (Aug. 27, 2025). 
21 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 26 of 28
principle that all executive power is vested in the President.โ  Consumersโ Rsch. v. CPSC, 98 F.4th 
646, 656 (5th Cir. 2024) (Oldham, J., joined by seven other judges, dissenting from denial of 
rehearing en banc).   As DOJ recently conceded in trying to defend the Presidentโs firings of board 
members of a different agency:  
The early Congresses further provided that the Banks of the United Statesโlike the 
Federal Reserveโwould have a degree of insulation from the Presidentโs control.  
Congress provided that all of the First Bankโs directors and 80% of the Second 
Bankโs directors would not be subject to presidential removal at all, while the 
Federal Reserve Governors may be removed by the President only โfor cause.โ  The 
Banks of the United States and their successor in the Federal Reserve represent a 
unique institution with a unique history and background.  Its historical pedigree 
cannot be generally extrapolated to other federal entities.  
 
Harris v. Bessent, No. 25-5037, Reply Br. for Appellants at 15 (D.C. Cir. Apr. 11, 2025) (internal 
citations omitted).  The Government should have to live by its words argued to the Court from just 
four months ago. 
The President has no legitimate interest in manipulating the composition of the Federal 
Reserve Board so that he can dictate interest rates.  As the Supreme Court recently reiterated, โ[t]he 
Federal Reserve is a uniquely structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the distinct historical 
tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States.โ  Trump v. Wilcox, 145 S. Ct. at 1415. 
The President seeks to upend that tradition.  Governor Cook asks only that the Court preserve the 
status quo, as such relief would vindicate important equities and public interests, while imposing 
a de minimis burden on the President, who seeks to exercise power outside of his Article II and 
statutory authority, and will soon enough have an opportunity to present his case and seek to defend 
his unprecedented conduct.  
22 
 

  Case 1:25-cv-02903-JMC     Document 2-1     Filed 08/28/25     Page 27 of 28
CONCLUSION 
In light of President Trumpโs first-of-its kind attack on the independence of the Federal 
Reserve Board, and the clear and imminent harm facing Governor Cook should her removal be 
effectuated, Governor Cook moves for an immediate temporary restraining order (1) declaring that 
President Trumpโs August 25, 2025 attempted firing of Governor Cook is unlawful under the 
Federal Reserve Act and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment, and that Governor Cook 
is still a member of the Federal Reserve Board; and (2) enjoining Defendants the Federal Reserve 
Board  of  Governors,  collectively  and/or  individually,  and  Chairman  Jerome  Powell  from 
effectuating in any manner Governor Cookโs purported removal from her position or in any way 
treating her as having been removed, or denying or obstructing her in accessing any of the benefits 
or resources of her Board position.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA 
 
 
   
LISA D. COOK, in her official capacity as a   
member of the Board of Governors of the   
Federal Reserve System and her personal   
capacity,   Civil Action No. 25-__________

DONALD J. TRUMP, in his official

FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM, both 
collectively and in their individual official 
capacities,   
Constitution Ave NW &, 20th St NW,

of the Federal Reserve System,
